Fig. 3 Preparation and functionalization of free-standing nitrogen-doped carbon-based catalyst electrodes for electrocatalytic N2 fixation Qing Qin a b c ⁎ Francesco Brandi a Bolortuya Badamdorj a Chemistry Jena, Institut für Technische Chemie und Umweltchemie, Friedrich- Schiller-Universität Jena, Philosophenweg 7a, D-07743 Jena, Germany ⁎ Corresponding authors. Nitrogen-doped carbon-based materials have been recently explored as promising electrocatalysts for N2 fixation. Herein, a nitrogen-doped carbon film as a self-standing electrode is synthesized through a novel and scalable strategy. After the film synthesis, a thin layer of Au nanoparticles is deposited, significantly enhancing the performance of such films in electrocatalytic N2 reduction. Owing to the exposed active sites and unique free-standing structure, it shows desirable performance towards electrochemical N2 fixation with a high Faradaic efficiency of 6.4 %, and a NH3 production rate of 18.3 μg h−1 cm−2 at a low given potential of -0.05 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode. Such performance is superior in comparison with Au-nanoparticles-modified nitrogen-doped carbon powder. Further comparison of nitrogen-doped carbon film and nitrogen-doped carbon powder also demonstrates the benefits of the free-standing structure in comparison to film-based materials in terms of charge transfer and active sites per electrode surface area. Graphical abstract A novel nitrogen doped carbon (NDC) and gold deposited on NDC free-standing electrodes was presented for the an efficient electrocatalytic N2 fixation to NH3. These free-standing electrodes showed superior performance in the electrocatalytic N2 fixation to NH3 with respect to the powder counterparts NDC deposited on carbon paper. Image, graphical abstract Keywords N-doped porous carbon Free-standing electrode Electrocatalysis N2 fixation 1 Introduction The nitrogen cycle is a crucial process for the life and development of human beings. For example amino acids, the molecular building-blocks of proteins are all containing nitrogen and are part of this cycle [1–2]. The simplest and most widely applied nitrogen-containing chemical compound that chemically useful is ammonia (NH3) [3–4]. Since many decades, the Haber-Bosch process is the industrial method of choice to produce NH3 through direct hydrogenation of nitrogen (N2) molecules at high temperature (573-773 K) and pressure (15-25 MPa) using metal-based catalysts [5–6]. The necessary hydrogen is mostly produced from energy-intensive steam reforming of methane, accounting for more than 2 % of the worldwide energy consumption. NH3 production causes massive CO2 release (more than 1 t of CO2 per 1 t of NH3) [7]. Alternative NH3 synthesis strategies have attracted increasing interests, especially those that can be coupled to renewable energy sources including N2 fixation through photocatalysis, electrocatalysis, or photoelectrocatalysis [8–11]. Among them, the electrochemical N2 reduction reaction (NRR) is especially attractive as it can be driven by renewable electricity, water can be used instead of hydrogen, and it can be operated under ambient conditions [12–14]. Despite great research efforts, electrocatalytic reduction of the chemically highly inert N2 molecules is still suffering from a number of limitations such as the strong competition from hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and limited NH3 production rate, especially in aqueous electrolytes. Most of the researchers are currently trying to address these problems with the development of (often relatively sophisticated) catalytic nanomaterials [14–16]. Design of NRR catalysts includes different chemical compositions, ranging from transitional and noble metal- to rare-earth-elements based materials, and from metal- to non-metal-based compounds [17–21]. Carbon-based materials are very promising candidates as metal-free NRR catalysts due to their low cost, good electrochemical stability and tunable chemical architecture [22–24]. Heteroatoms, such as B, N, O, F, P or Cl, can be doped into the carbon framework, and modified surface chemistry, charge distribution and electronic structure may generate active sites for N2 reduction [19,25-31]. Besides, metal-based materials can be deposited on the carbon surface. This can cause charge transfer between metal and carbon framework and can lead to synergistic effects, which are often needed for catalytic N2 activation [11, 30,32-35]. In contrast to the catalyst design and studies on the electrolyte, the electrode design and manufacturing as such received by far less attention although several studies have shown that electrode composition, porosity, and engineering offer huge space for significant improvement, particularly for higher NH3 production rates [36]. Especially the direct shaping of carbon-based catalysts into self-standing electrodes seems to be a straightforward method towards a high density of catalytically active sites per electrode surface without losing the electric conductivity [37]. Despite that promise, most of the currently tested carbon-based powder materials are applied in NRR by preparing a catalyst ink and depositing it on a conductive electrode. Carbon paper and carbon cloth are the commonly used supporting electrodes but are themselves NRR-inactive in the applied electrolytes. After deposition from dispersion, catalyst particles are often randomly distributed on the carbon paper with poor contact to the substrate surface. This leads to additional resistance and thus inhomogeneous potential distribution throughout the catalytically active particles. Besides, recycling of those powder catalysts is difficult and they suffer from limited areal current and for that low space-time-yield of NH3 [38]. Therefore, the synthesis of self-supported and free-standing carbon films as electrodes can in principle improve the NRR performance from a number of perspectives [37]. It is also desirable to systematically compare the NRR performance between carbon powders and films of comparable composition to get an understanding for the structure-property relationships and in that way to guide further catalysts and electrode design. Herein, a novel strategy was applied to synthesize a porous N-doped carbon (NDC) film (NDC-Film). Intriguingly, this film shows improved Faradic efficiency (FE) and NH3 production rate in comparison to porous N-doped carbon powder (NDC-Powder). Moreover, to further improve the NRR activity, a thin layer of active Au nanoparticles was deposited on the surface of the NDC-Film by impregnation. This metal deposition results in increased FE and NH3 production rate. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All the materials were utilized as received without further purification. The detailed list of utilized chemicals, suppliers, and purities can be found in the supporting information (SI) file. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis and characterization The free-standing porous NDC-Film was synthesizing following the procedure previously reported by our group [39]. The NDC-Powder was obtained by grinding the NDC-Film in a mortar. Therefore, Au-NDC-Film and Au-NDC-Powder catalysts were prepared using dep impregnation methods onto the as-prepared NDC-Film and NDC-Powder, respectively. The detailed synthetic procedures of the aforementioned catalysts are reported in the Experimental section of SI. The prepared materials were characterized via X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), N2 physisorption, elemental analysis (EA), and inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy elemental analysis (ICP-OES). The detailed description of the applied characterization procedures is reported in the SI. 2.3 Electrochemical performance measurements The electrochemical performance of the prepared catalysts, i.e. NDC-Film, NDC-Powder, Au-NDC-Film, and Au-NDC-Powder, were evaluated using an H-type cell with a three-electrode system equipped with catalyst film or carbon paper coated with catalyst as working cathodic electrode, a platinum foil in the anodic part, and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as reference, viz. Figure S8 in SI. The NRR performances of the prepared catalysts were tested via Linear Swap voltammetry (LSV), cyclic voltammetry (CV), and Chronoamperometry measurements. The product quantification was performed through indophenol blue and Nesslers methods for NH3, and Watt and Crisp method for N2H4. The description of the applied methods, as well as the product quantification procedures is reported in details in SI. 3 Results and discussions The free-standing porous NDC-Film (Figure S1) was synthesized according to our previous report, based on a physical mixture of semolina as a sustainable carbon source, urea, glucose, water, and ZnO nanoparticles (20 nm) as a porogen, which is described in detail in the experimental section, cf., supporting information (SI) [39]. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was applied to investigate the structure and morphology of the NDC-Film (Figure S2), and indicates the existence of hierarchical pores on length scales from micrometers to nanometers. As a reference material, NDC-Powder was simply obtained by grinding the film into powder without further treatment. XRD patterns for NDC-Film and NDC-Powder both show two broad peaks at 26o and 44o (Figure S3), attributed to the typical (002) and (101) reflections of turbostratic carbon structure without pronounced long-term ordering. N2 physisorption at 77 K of the NDC-Film shows a hierarchical pore structure with high specific surface area (SSA) of 660 m2 g−1 and total pore volume of 0.48 cm3 g−1 (Figure S4 and Table S1). A comparable pore structure seems to be present in the NDC-Powder (Figure S4). N and C content were analyzed by elemental analysis, showing that the mass content of nitrogen and carbon are 4 % and 80 %, respectively. Different amounts of Au nanoparticles (with the size between 1 and 100 nm) were then deposited on the NDC-Film by simple impregnation. The resulting samples are denoted as Au-NDC-Film-1 and Au-NDC-Film-2 with Au loadings of 0.08 wt.-% and 0.02 wt.-%, respectively, measured by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). SEM images of Au-NDC-Film-1 show similar surface morphology as for the NDC-Film (Fig. 1 a). Uniform element distribution of C, N and Au is demonstrated by energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy (Fig. 1b-d). From the SEM image at higher resolution (Fig. 1e), abundant Au nanoparticles with polydisperse particle size (with an average diameter of 65 nm). Moreover, Fig. 1e shows that the Au nanoparticles are uniformly distributed on the NDC-Film surface can be seen. The relatively large diameter of these particles is also demonstrated by the sharp characteristic reflections of Au0 in the XRD patterns for Au-NDC-Film-1 (Fig. 1f), namely (111) at 36°, (200) at 44°, (220) at 63°, and (311) at 77°. XPS results (Fig. 1g) show a pair of spin-orbit doublets at 84.0 and 87.6 eV, respectively, indicating the existence of Au0 [40]. The successful construction of the Au-NDC-Film-2 with lower Au loading is also proven by SEM-EDX results (Figure S5) and XRD patterns (Fig. 1f). The electronic structure of the deposited Au nanoparticles in Au-NDC-Film-2 is similar with the Au nanoparticles in Au-NDC-Film-1 (Fig. 1g). Notably, compared with the Au-NDC-Film-1, the Au-NDC-Film-2 exhibited smaller and less polydisperse Au nanoparticles (with an average size of 40 nm). N2 physisorption measurements (Figure S6) demonstrate that the porous structure of the Au-NDC-Film remains after Au loading. SSAs of 712 m2 g−1 for Au-NDC-Film-1 and 608.1 m2 g−1 for Au-NDC-Film-2 are in the same range as the SSAs of NDC-Film (Table S1). Similar shapes of the physisorption isotherms confirm that the pore size distributions also remain unaffected by the Au loading. Besides, Au-NDC-Film-1 and Au-NDC-Film-2 were also ground into powder without further treatment. Resulting materials are denoted as Au-NDC-Film-G-1 and Au-NDC-Film-G-2. As a comparison, NDC-powder was also modified with Au nanoparticles (denoted as Au-NDC-Powder), which appear in the form of Au nanoparticles, indicated by the characteristic Au peaks in XRD patterns (Figure S7a). ICP-OES characterization shows an Au loading of 0.02 wt.% in the Au-NDC-Powder, which is in the same range as forAu-NDC-Film-2. In accordance, the deconvolution of XPS spectra (Figure S7b) of Au 4f exhibits a pair of spin-orbit doublets, attributed to Au0. In view of the unique free-standing structure of Au-NDC-Film-1, its performance in NRR as a binder-free electrode was studied in an H-cell (Figure S8). Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves under Ar and N2-saturated electrolyte solution indicate an obvious current response if N2 is present (Fig. 2 a). Furthermore, chronoamperometry tests with Au-NDC-Film-1 were carried out under different given potentials within the range from -0.05 V to -0.3 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) (Fig. 2b). The total NH3 yield was calculated from the NH4 + calibration curve (Figure S9), and the corresponding FE and NH3 production rate were then calculated (Fig. 2c and d), cf., supporting information for detailed NH3 yield calculation and equations. A maximum FE of 6.4 % with a high NH3 production rate of 18.3 μg h−1 cm−2 can be achieved at a low potential of -0.1 V vs. RHE. With more negative applied potentials, both the FE and NH3 production rate decrease due to the dominating HER. During the cycling test, both FE and NH3 production remained constant (Fig. 3 a) and there is no obvious change of the film shape (Figure S10) after 4 cycles for the Au-NDC-Film-1 electrode, demonstrating chemical and mechanical stability. After the cycle test, characterization via XRD for Au-NDC-Film-1 shows that Au remained in its metallic form (Figure S11). The product selectivity is also an additional parameter to evaluate the catalyst performance in this reaction. Thus, hydrazine as another possible product was also detected under different potentials. Au-NDC-Film-1 electrode shows an 100 % N2 selectivity to NH3 as no hydrazine traces was detected (Figure S12). Based on the suggested protocol for NH3 detection, N2 gas was pre-treated in a basic solution to remove the impurities (such NOx) in the supplied gas and then introduced into the electrochemical cell. The same electrochemical protocol was also conducted under Ar-saturated electrolyte to exclude the possible nitrogen contamination from external sources (Figure S13), including NH3 in the atmosphere, H-cell, electrolytes and nafion membrane [41]. Other control experiments were also performed to confirm the nitrogen source under the applied potentials. Detection of NH3 under open-circuit and in the electrolyte solution before conducting the NRR experiment (Fig. 3b), were also carried out to confirm N sources. All those control experiments confirm that the produced NH3 must come only from the fed N2 gas. As a comparison, the NRR performance of Au-NDC-Film-2 electrode was also tested (Fig. 3c), showing a lower FE of 4.98 % and area-normalized NH3 production rate of 12.8 μg h−1 cm−2, which could be explained by the lower overall Au loading with less active sites. Besides, Au-NDC-Film-G-1 and Au-NDC-Film-G-2 were prepared into catalyst ink and then supported on the commercial carbon paper as NRR electrode (Fig. 3c), which exhibit an inferior NRR activity in comparison to the free-standing films with an FE and NH3 production rate of 4.1 % and 7.28 μg h−1 cm−2 for Au-NDC-Film-G-1, as well as 3.7 % and 6.31 μg h−1 cm−2 for Au-NDC-Film-G-2 at a potential of -0.1 V vs. RHE, respectively. In addition, Au-NDC-Powder was also deposited on carbon paper and tested in NRR. The FE can only be achieved as 3.1 % with a NH3 production rate of 4.28 μg h−1 cm−2 under the potential of -0.1 V vs. RHE. Considering the same amount of Au loading between Au-NDC-Powder and Au-NDC-Film-2, both the FE and NH3 production rate are higher in Au-NDC-Film-2, especially showing a 3-time increase towards NH3 production rate. A comparable observation can also be made when NDC-Film and NDC-Powder without any Au loading are compared. At the potential of -0.1 V. vs. RHE, FE and NH3 production rate of NDC-Film can be obtained as 3.1 % and 6.15 μg h−1 cm−2, respectively, which were enhanced over twice compared with them of NDC-Powder (1.2 % and 1.81 μg h−1 cm−2, respectively) (Fig. 3c). Although pure carbon paper without catalyst loading is also self-supported, it exhibited no activity toward NRR (Figure S14). All the above observations highlight the advantage of a compact and free-standing film structure for electrocatalytic ammonia production. To get insights into the origin of the enhanced NRR activity of film-based catalyst, electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were measured (Figure S15). It can be observed that the semicircle at the high frequency in the Nyquist plot of film-based materials (NDC-Film, Au-NDC-Film-1 and Au-NDC-Film-2) is much smaller than that of powder-based materials loaded on the carbon paper (NDC-Powder, Au-NDC- Powder, Au-NDC-Film-G-1 and Au-NDC-Film-G-2), suggesting the lower charge transfer resistance of film-based materials and thus implying their fast charge transfer ability during NRR. Compact stacking of catalyst nanoparticles within the film can result in homogeneous potential distribution and reduced charge transfer resistance on the electrode. In addition, further comparison of LSV curves shows the increased capacitive current densities of NDC-Film than that of NDC-Powder within the lower potential (Figure S16), which can be attributed to the large double-layer capacitance (Cdl) of NDC-Film. The same phenomenon is also seen in Au-NDC-Film-2 electrode by comparison with the Au-NDC-Powder electrode. The increased Cdl effectively implies larger electrochemically active surface areas of film-based electrode, thus possibly revealing more active sites exposed on the film surface for the enhanced activity towards N2 activation when related to the electrode surface. 3 Conclusions In conclusion, a novel free-standing nitrogen-doped carbon-based film was constructed as a binder-free electrode for the electrocatalytic synthesis of NH3. The synthetic approach of free-standing shaped-carbon supports has been already demonstrated to be cheap, scalable, and stable catalyst in the framework of heterogeneous catalysis in continuous flow systems. [35, 39,42-43] Nevertheless, herein this free-standing procedure is firstly applied for electrochemistry purposes. This demonstrates its intrinsic versatility. Compared with the most commonly applied catalyst powders deposited on carbon paper, the introduction of a compact structure as free-standing electrode leads to a homogeneous potential distribution, decreased charge resistance, and a significantly enhanced number of catalytically active sites per electrode area. Thus, such a film electrode enables NRR with enhanced FE and NH3 production rate. We believe that this work envisages the pave towards new opportunities in NRR catalyst design by directly shaping materials into free-standing electrodes. Those materials include but are not at all limited to carbon-based materials. As a rather personal site conclusion, we also believe such a film electrode can be applied as gas diffusion electrode to further increase the NH3 production rate. coredata.dc:description: Nitrogen-doped carbon-based materials have been recently explored as promising electrocatalysts for N2 fixation. Herein, a nitrogen-doped carbon film as a self-standing electrode is synthesized through a novel and scalable strategy. After the film synthesis, a thin layer of Au nanoparticles is deposited, significantly enhancing the performance of such films in electrocatalytic N2 reduction. Owing to the exposed active sites and unique free-standing structure, it shows desirable performance towards electrochemical N2 fixation with a high Faradaic efficiency of 6.4 %, and a NH3 production rate of 18.3 μg h−1 cm−2 at a low given potential of -0.05 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode. Such performance is superior in comparison with Au-nanoparticles-modified nitrogen-doped carbon powder. Further comparison of nitrogen-doped carbon film and nitrogen-doped carbon powder also demonstrates the benefits of the free-standing structure in comparison to film-based materials in terms of charge transfer and active sites per electrode surface area.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation and functionalization of free-standing nitrogen-doped carbon-based catalyst electrodes for electrocatalytic N2 fixation
